00001 /*
00002 Functions to compare floating point numbers using
00003 integer operations
00004 
00005 Original Author: Bruce Dawson
00006 */
00007 
00008 #include <float.h>
00009 #include <math.h>
00010 #include <assert.h>
00011 #include <stdio.h>
00012 
00013 // Initial AlmostEqualULPs version - fast and simple, but
00014 // some limitations.
00015 bool AlmostEqualUlps(float A, float B, int maxUlps)
00016 {
00017     if (A == B)
00018         return true; 
00019     int intDiff = abs(*(int*)&A - *(int*)&B);
00020     if (intDiff <= maxUlps)
00021         return true;
00022     return false;
00023 }
00024 
00025 // Usable AlmostEqual function
00026 bool AlmostEqual2sComplement(float A, float B, int maxUlps)
00027 {
00028     // Make sure maxUlps is non-negative and small enough that the
00029     // default NAN won't compare as equal to anything.
00030     assert(maxUlps > 0 && maxUlps < 4 * 1024 * 1024);
00031     int aInt = *(int*)&A;
00032     // Make aInt lexicographically ordered as a twos-complement int
00033     if (aInt < 0)
00034         aInt = 0x80000000 - aInt;
00035     // Make bInt lexicographically ordered as a twos-complement int
00036     int bInt = *(int*)&B;
00037     if (bInt < 0)
00038         bInt = 0x80000000 - bInt;
00039     int intDiff = abs(aInt - bInt);
00040     if (intDiff <= maxUlps)
00041         return true;
00042     return false;
00043 }
00044 
00045 // Support functions and conditional compilation directives for the
00046 // master AlmostEqual function.
00047 #define INFINITYCHECK
00048 #define NANCHECK
00049 #define SIGNCHECK
00050 
00051 inline bool IsInfinite(float A)
00052 {
00053     const int kInfAsInt = 0x7F800000;
00054 
00055     // An infinity has an exponent of 255 (shift left 23 positions) and
00056     // a zero mantissa. There are two infinities - positive and negative.
00057     if ((*(int*)&A & 0x7FFFFFFF) == kInfAsInt)
00058         return true;
00059     return false;
00060 }
00061 
00062 inline bool IsNan(float A)
00063 {
00064     // A NAN has an exponent of 255 (shifted left 23 positions) and
00065     // a non-zero mantissa.
00066     int exp = *(int*)&A & 0x7F800000;
00067     int mantissa = *(int*)&A & 0x007FFFFF;
00068     if (exp == 0x7F800000 && mantissa != 0)
00069         return true;
00070     return false;
00071 }
00072 
00073 inline int Sign(float A)
00074 {
00075     // The sign bit of a number is the high bit.
00076     return (*(int*)&A) & 0x80000000;
00077 }
00078 
00079 // This is the 'final' version of the AlmostEqualUlps function.
00080 // The optional checks are included for completeness, but in many
00081 // cases they are not necessary, or even not desirable.
00082 bool AlmostEqualUlpsFinal(float A, float B, int maxUlps)
00083 {
00084     // There are several optional checks that you can do, depending
00085     // on what behavior you want from your floating point comparisons.
00086     // These checks should not be necessary and they are included
00087     // mainly for completeness.
00088 
00089 #ifdef  INFINITYCHECK
00090     // If A or B are infinity (positive or negative) then
00091     // only return true if they are exactly equal to each other -
00092     // that is, if they are both infinities of the same sign.
00093     // This check is only needed if you will be generating
00094     // infinities and you don't want them 'close' to numbers
00095     // near FLT_MAX.
00096     if (IsInfinite(A) || IsInfinite(B))
00097         return A == B;
00098 #endif
00099 
00100 #ifdef  NANCHECK
00101     // If A or B are a NAN, return false. NANs are equal to nothing,
00102     // not even themselves.
00103     // This check is only needed if you will be generating NANs
00104     // and you use a maxUlps greater than 4 million or you want to
00105     // ensure that a NAN does not equal itself.
00106     if (IsNan(A) || IsNan(B))
00107         return false;
00108 #endif
00109 
00110 #ifdef  SIGNCHECK
00111     // After adjusting floats so their representations are lexicographically
00112     // ordered as twos-complement integers a very small positive number
00113     // will compare as 'close' to a very small negative number. If this is
00114     // not desireable, and if you are on a platform that supports
00115     // subnormals (which is the only place the problem can show up) then
00116     // you need this check.
00117     // The check for A == B is because zero and negative zero have different
00118     // signs but are equal to each other.
00119     if (Sign(A) != Sign(B))
00120         return A == B;
00121 #endif
00122 
00123     int aInt = *(int*)&A;
00124     // Make aInt lexicographically ordered as a twos-complement int
00125     if (aInt < 0)
00126         aInt = 0x80000000 - aInt;
00127     // Make bInt lexicographically ordered as a twos-complement int
00128     int bInt = *(int*)&B;
00129     if (bInt < 0)
00130         bInt = 0x80000000 - bInt;
00131 
00132     // Now we can compare aInt and bInt to find out how far apart A and B
00133     // are.
00134     int intDiff = abs(aInt - bInt);
00135     if (intDiff <= maxUlps)
00136         return true;
00137     return false;
00138 }
